Effects of rhodium catalyst support and particle size on dry reforming of methane at moderate temperatures Katsuya Shimura ⁎ Tadahiro Fujitani Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), 1-1-1 Higashi, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8565, Japan Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) 1-1-1 Higashi Tsukuba Ibaraki 305-8565 Japan Interdisciplinary Research Center for Catalytic Chemistry, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), 1-1-1 Higashi, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8565, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Dry reforming of methane at 400–600°C was studied over Rh catalysts with different supports (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, α-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Y2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO, SiO2-TiO2), Rh particle sizes (1.5–15.6 nm), and acidic properties (acidic site density, 0.37–3.40 mmol g−1). Catalysts with a high density of strongly acidic sites (e.g., α-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO) showed low activity and gradually deactivated with time on stream; in contrast, catalysts with a low density of strongly acidic sites (e.g., TiO2, γ-Al2O3) showed high, stable activity. Rh/SiO2-TiO2 showed the best performance, with H2 and CO yields of 1.8% and 4.2% at 400°C and yields 37.3% and 53.1% at 600°C, respectively. Catalyst activity depended strongly on Rh particle size; specific activity increased with decreasing particle size, indicating that Rh-catalyzed dry reforming of methane is structure-sensitive. The support type influenced not only the dispersion and reducibility of the Rh particles but also the specific activity of the catalysts. CO temperature-programmed desorption and FT-IR suggested that electron-deficient Rhδ+ species were generated by electronic interactions between the Rh particles and the support, and the number of these species strongly influenced the overall catalytic activity. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Rhodium catalyst Support effect Particle size effect 1 Introduction Owing to concerns about global warming and oil depletion, dry reforming of methane (DRM, conversion of CH4 and CO2 into syngas [H2 + CO], reaction (1)) has recently been attracting attention [1–4]. Methane is abundant in natural resources such as natural gas and methane hydrate; and CO2, a greenhouse gas, can be collected in large quantities from the atmosphere. In addition, CH4 is also the main constituent of biogas (50–70% CH4 and 25–50% CO2), which is produced by anaerobic digestion of organic waste or by fermentation of biomass and can be directly used for DRM [5]. Furthermore, the syngas generated by DRM is a promising platform chemical because it can be converted into liquid fuels and chemicals such as ethylene, propylene, BTX (benzene, toluene, xylenes), and DME (dimethyl ether) via Fischer–Tropsch synthesis or methanol synthesis. Development of a solar–chemical energy transmission system utilizing the high endothermicity of DRM is also underway [1, 6, 7]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 → 2 H 2 + 2 CO Δ H 298 K 0 = + 247 kJ mo l − 1 DRM has several advantages over other syngas-production methods such as steam reforming of CH4 (CH4 + H2O → 3H2 + CO). First, because both CH4 and CO2 are greenhouse gases, DRM can remove larger amounts of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. Second, DRM generates a 1:1 mixture of H2 and CO, which can be directly used to synthesize long-chain hydrocarbons and oxygenated chemicals such as acetic acid, DME, and oxo-alcohols [4]. Third, the estimated operation cost of DRM is lower than that of other syngas-production methods [1]. Despite the many advantages of DRM, its industrial applications remain limited. Because CH4 and CO2 are very stable, the C–H bond of CH4 and the C–O bond of CO2 are difficult to activate. In addition, because of its high endothermicity, DRM typically requires high temperature (>800°C), which not only increases operating costs but also causes catalyst deactivation owing to sintering of the active metal species. In addition, catalyst deactivation due to carbon deposition often occurs during DRM. Carbon forms primarily via two reactions: CH4 decomposition (reaction (2)) and the Boudouard reaction (reaction (3)). It is reported that carbon formation occurs due to CH4 decomposition above 557°C and due to the Boudouard reaction below 700°C [1, 4]. Apart from CH4 decomposition and the Boudouard reaction, several side reactions (e.g., the reverse water–gas shift reaction (reaction (4)) and methanation (reaction (5)) can occur simultaneously with DRM, depending on the reaction conditions. These side reactions strongly affect the H2/CO ratio in the syngas product. For industrial applications of DRM, the development of a process with high yield and selectivity under mild conditions is necessary. (2) C H 4 → C + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 K 0 = + 75 kJ mo l − 1 (3) 2 CO → C + C O 2 Δ H 298 K 0 = − 172 kJ mo l − 1 (4) C O 2 + H 2 → CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 K 0 = + 41 kJ mo l − 1 (5) C O 2 + 4 H 2 → C H 4 + 2 H 2 O Δ H 298 K 0 = − 165 kJ mo l − 1 Although DRM is typically carried out at high temperatures, DRM at low temperature is not impossible. Thermodynamic calculations have shown that the equilibrium conversions of CH4 and CO2 at 300°C are about 60% and 50%, respectively [2, 8], indicating that the activation of both CH4 and CO2 at temperatures as low as 300°C would be thermodynamically feasible if more-efficient catalytic systems could be developed. Indeed, the development of catalysts with high, stable activity for DRM at lower temperatures has recently been attracting growing interest [2, 9–12]. Group 8–10 metals (e.g., Ni, Co, Ru, Pt, Pd, Ir, and Rh) are catalytically active for DRM [1–4, 13]. Among these metals, Ni has been studied the most extensively because of its low cost and the relatively high activity of Ni-based catalysts for DRM [2–4, 14–17]. However, Ni catalysts typically suffer from deactivation due to excessive carbon deposition and severe thermal sintering, although the former process can be suppressed by using a support or promoter (or both) with strong basicity and high oxygen mobility (e.g., La2O3, MgO, CeO2, or ZrO2) [5, 17–21]. Compared with Ni catalysts, noble metal catalysts are much more resistant to carbon deposition and sintering, although their high cost is prohibitive for many industrial uses [1, 22–24]. Rhodium in particular is an excellent DRM catalyst owing to its high activity and resistance to coke formation [6, 7, 25]; and there have been a number of studies of Rh catalysts supported on various metal oxides, such as SiO2 (amorphous and mesoporous) [26–29], γ-Al2O3 [21, 30–33], α-Al2O3 [18–20], ZrO2 [34], La2O3 [35], CeO2 [36], CeO2-ZrO2 [5], zeolites [37], La2Zr2O7 [38], and La2Ti2O7 [39]. However, most of these studies involved temperatures exceeding 600°C, and there have been only a few studies at moderate temperatures (400–600°C) [29]. In the present study, we investigated DRM at moderate temperatures (400–600°C) over supported Rh catalysts, paying particular attention to the effects of the catalyst support and the Rh particle size. The effects of Rh catalyst supports and particle size have already been studied by several research groups [40–48], but the results of these previous studies are contradictory. For example, Mark and Maier reported that catalyst activity depends solely on the accessible metal surface area and is not influenced by pore structure or the type of support [40]; the only roles of the support are to disperse the metal particles and increase their surface area. In addition, Bitter et al. [41] and Wei and Iglesia [42] also reported that the support has no effect on the turnover rate of Rh catalysts. In contrast, Verykios et al. reported that the specific activity (turnover frequency [TOF]) of Rh catalysts depends strongly on the type of support and that the activity of the catalysts decreases in the order yttria-stabilized zirconia > γ-Al2O3 > TiO2 > SiO2 > La2O3 > MgO [43, 44]. Yokota et al. reported that the TOFs of supported Rh catalysts decrease in the order TiO2 > La2O3 ≈ CeO2 > ZrO2 ≈ MgO ≈ SiO2 ≈ MCM-41 > γ-Al2O3 and that the structure sensitivity exhibited by Rh catalysts for DRM is due to variations in the electronic interactions between Rh and the support surface [45]. Wang and Ruckenstein reported that reducible metal oxides such as Nb2O5, ZrO2, and TiO2 are unsuitable for DRM because catalysts on these supports show low activity, very long induction periods, or deactivation behavior [46]. In contrast, catalysts supported on irreducible metal oxides such as MgO and γ-Al2O3 show high, stable activity. Bhat and Sachtler reported that CH4 conversion during DRM over supported Rh catalysts decreases in the order Rh/NaY ≈ Rh/NaZSM-5 > Rh/Al2O3 > Rh/SiO2 [47]. In contrast, Portugal et al. reported that the TOFs for CO formation over Rh catalysts supported on a normal metal oxide (γ-Al2O3, Nb2O5, or TiO2) are significantly higher than the TOFs for CO formation over zeolite-supported catalysts [48]. Because of the above-described contradictory results, there is no consensus regarding the effects of Rh catalyst supports and particle sizes on DRM. Two explanations for the contradictions can be considered. One is that the reaction temperatures used in the above-described studies varied considerably, from 450 to 850°C; and the other is that the effects of the support were evaluated with Rh catalysts with different Rh particle sizes. To isolate the effect of the support, the activity of Rh catalysts with different supports but similar Rh particle sizes must be compared. Furthermore, any impurities (e.g., sulfur) in the support can be expected to affect the performance of Rh catalysts, which might explain the different orders of activity reported in the literature [43, 44, 49]. In this study, ten types of metal oxides (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, α-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Y2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO, and SiO2-TiO2) were tested as supports for Rh catalysts with various Rh particle sizes, which were prepared by varying the Rh loading from 0.5 to 5 wt% for each support. The effects of support type, Rh particle size, and reaction temperature on catalyst performance were systematically studied. In addition, the Rh catalysts were characterized by several analytical techniques, and the factors that influenced the DRM activity of the catalysts are discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supported Rh catalysts were prepared from RhCl3•3H2O (99.5%, Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Corporation) by means of an impregnation method. The following supports were used: SiO2 (P-6, Fuji Silysia), γ-Al2O3 (JRC-ALO-7, reference catalyst of the Catalysis Society of Japan), α-Al2O3 (AKP-3000, Sumitomo Chemical), TiO2 (P-25, Evonik), ZrO2 (Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co.), CeO2 (Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co.), SiO2-Al2O3 (JRC-SAL-2, reference catalyst of the Catalysis Society of Japan), SiO2-MgO (JRC-SM-2, reference catalyst of the Catalysis Society of Japan), SiO2-TiO2 (Fuji Silysia; TiO2 content, 5%), and Y2O3, which was prepared from Y(NO3)3•nH2O (99.9%, Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemical Corporation) and urea by means of a homogeneous precipitation method similar to that described previously [50]. The Rh loading was varied from 0.5 to 5 wt%. The impregnated powders were dried at 110°C for 12 h and then calcined in air at 300°C for 4 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts were measured at −196°C with an ASAP 2020 system (Micromeritics). Prior to the measurements, catalyst samples (0.15 g) were degassed at 400°C for 4 h under vacuum. Specific surface areas were determined by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model for absorption in a relative pressure range of 0.05–0.30. Total pore volumes were calculated from the amounts of N2 gas adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99. Pore size distributions were determined by means of the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda model from the desorption branches of the N2 isotherms. Temperature-programmed reduction under H2 (H2-TPR) was carried out with a BELCAT-B chemisorption analyzer (BEL Japan). Calcined catalyst (0.10 g) was mounted in a quartz cell and heated to 800°C at a rate of 5°C min−1 in a flow of 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1). Before reaching the thermal conductivity detector, the effluent gas was passed through a trap containing 5A molecular sieves to remove the water produced during calcination. Peak deconvolution was carried out with the ChemMaster analysis software (MicrotracBEL) using Gaussian functions. The reduction degrees of the supported Rh particles were calculated from the amounts of H2 consumed at less than 500°C, assuming that Rh was deposited as Rh2O3 before H2 reduction pretreatment. Pulse adsorption of H2 was measured with a BEL-METAL-1 metal dispersion rate analyzer (BEL Japan Inc.) as follows. The catalyst (0.05–0.10 g) was reduced at 500°C for 1 h in a flow of 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) and then held at 500°C for 1 h in a flow of Ar (30 mL min−1) to desorb the residual chemisorbed H2. After the reduced catalyst was cooled to 100°C in a flow of Ar, H2 was pulsed over it until no H2 adsorption was detected. Rh dispersion was calculated by assuming 1:2 stoichiometry for adsorbed H2 and surface Rh atoms. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed with a BELCAT-B chemisorption analyzer (BEL Japan) as follows. The catalyst (0.10 g) was heated at 500°C for 1 h under a He flow (30 mL min−1), cooled to 100°C in a He flow, and exposed to 5% NH3-He (30 mL min−1) at 100°C for 0.5 h. Then physisorbed NH3 was removed under a He flow for 0.5 h at the same temperature. Finally, TPD was performed by heating the catalyst to 800°C at a rate of 10°C min−1 in flowing He (30 mL min−1). The densities of weakly and strongly acidic sites were calculated from the amount of NH3 desorption. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO (CO-TPD) was performed with a BELCAT-B chemisorption analyzer (BEL Japan) as follows. The catalyst (0.10 g) was reduced at 500°C for 1 h in a flow of 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1), purged with He (30 mL min−1) at 500°C for 1 h, cooled to 100°C in a flow of He, and exposed to 10% CO-He (30 mL min−1) at 100°C for 0.5 h. Then the catalyst bed was swept again with flowing He for 0.5 h. Finally, TPD was performed by heating the catalyst to 700°C at a rate of 10°C min−1 in flowing He (30 mL min−1). In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT/IR-6300 spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment and a MCT detector. The sample was placed in an infrared cell equipped with CaF2 windows. The spectra were obtained by collecting 128 scans at 4 cm−1 resolution. Prior to IR measurement, samples were reduced at 450°C for 0.5 h in a flow of 50% H2/N2 (40 ml min−1), cooled to room temperature in a flow of N2 (20 ml min−1), evacuated using a rotary pump for 30 min, and a background spectrum was recorded. Then, 10% CO/He (10 ml mn−1) was fed to the cell for 10 min. After adsorption of CO, the IR cell was evacuated again to remove gaseous CO for 15 min and then IR spectra were recorded. 2.3 Typical procedure for catalytic reactions Catalytic DRM reactions were performed in a fixed-bed down-flow quartz reactor operated at atmospheric pressure. Catalyst (0.20 g) that had been granulated to a particle size of 350–710 μm was loaded into the reactor along with quartz wool, which was placed before and after the catalyst bed. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in a flow of H2 (50 mL min−1) at 500°C for 1 h, and then the reactor was purged with Ar (100 mL min−1) for 30 min. The reaction was initiated by introducing the reaction gas mixture at a fixed temperature. Typically, the reaction was carried out at 400, 500, or 600°C for 8 h. The reaction gas mixture was composed of CH4 (50%) and CO2 (50%), and the total flow rate was 100 mL min−1. The effluent gas (containing CH4, CO2, H2, and CO) was analyzed by online gas chromatography on an instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a column of 5A molecular sieves. Multiple catalytic reactions were conducted for each catalyst, and the data reproducibility was confirmed (the experimental error was less than 5%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supported Rh (5%) catalysts Rhodium (5%) catalysts supported on the ten types of metal oxides (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, α-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Y2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO, and SiO2-TiO2) were characterized by N2 adsorption, H2 pulse adsorption, H2-TPR, and NH3-TPD. Their BET specific surface areas, pore volumes, and average pore sizes, which were measured by N2 adsorption, are listed in Table 1 . These three parameters varied considerably with the support type, ranging from 9.4 to 555 m2 g−1, from 0.04 to 1.81 cm3 g−1, and from 5.2 to 24.5 nm, respectively. BET specific surface area and pore volume were highest over Rh/SiO2 and lowest over Rh/α-Al2O3. Average pore size was lowest over Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 and highest over Rh/ΤiΟ2. Rh particle sizes, which were measured by H2 pulse adsorption, ranged from 3.0 to 15.6 nm (Table 1). For catalysts with BET specific surface areas of >90 m2 g−1, the Rh particle sizes were almost constant in the range of 3.0–4.1 nm, except in the case of Rh/SiO2-TiO2 (8.8 nm). In contrast, for catalysts with BET specific surface areas of <90 m2 g−1, Rh particle size tended to increase with decreasing surface area. The H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . In the profiles of Rh/ZrO2, Rh/TiO2, Rh/SiO2, Rh/α-Al2O3, and Rh/SiO2-TiO2, the only peak was an intense reduction peak at <150°C, which was attributed to reduction of Rh2O3 to Rh metal [51]; the shape of this peak varied slightly with the support type. In contrast, the profiles of Rh/SiO2-Al2O3, Rh/γ-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2-MgO, and Rh/CeO2 showed not only the peak assigned to reduction of Rh2O3 to Rh metal but also a shoulder peak at 150–400°C, which was attributed to reduction of RhO x species that interacted strongly with the support. Furthermore, the profile of Rh/CeO2 showed peaks at >600°C, which were assigned to reduction of CeO2 to Ce2O3 [18, 36, 51]. Finally, in the profile of Rh/Y2O3, broad reduction peaks were observed in the 50–750°C range. The marked difference between the profile of Rh/Y2O3 and the profiles of the other catalysts was probably due to the formation of a solid solution of Rh and Y2O3 (e.g., YRhO3) during the thermal pretreatment [52, 53]. Peak deconvolution of the H2-TPR profiles of Rh/SiO2-Al2O3, Rh/γ-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2-MgO, Rh/CeO2 and Rh/Y2O3 was carried out (Fig. S1). The profiles of these five catalysts were deconvoluted using five peaks, which were centered at <120°C (α), 120–150°C (β), 150–300°C (γ), 300–400°C (δ), and >400°C (ε). The profiles of Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 and Rh/γ-Al2O3 comprised peaks α and β (Table S1). The profiles of Rh/SiO2-MgO and Rh/CeO2 comprised peaks α, β, and γ and peaks α, γ, and δ, respectively. The profile of Rh/Y2O3 comprised peaks β, γ, δ, and ε. The deconvolution results indicate that the amounts of easily reducible Rh species in the catalysts decreased in the order Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 ≈ Rh/γ-Al2O3 > Rh/SiO2-MgO ≈ Rh/CeO2 > Rh/Y2O3. Furthermore, the reduction degrees of the supported Rh particles were roughly calculated from the amounts of H2 consumed at <500°C in the H2-TPR profiles, on the assumption that Rh was deposited as Rh2O3 before H2 reduction pretreatment (Table S2). The reduction degrees of Rh in the Rh(5%)/MO x catalysts were 63–261%. The reduction degrees for all but two of the catalysts (Rh/SiO2-MgO and Rh/Y2O3) were lower than 100% (63–96%), probably because some of the Rh particles had already been reduced during the time required for the TCD detector to stabilize before the start of measurement. Thus, these findings suggest that the Rh particles in these eight catalysts were almost completely reduced to the metallic state by H2 reduction pretreatment at 500°C. In contrast, the reduction degrees of Rh/SiO2-MgO and Rh/Y2O3 exceeded 100%, indicating that not only the Rh particles but also some of the support surface was reduced during the H2 reduction pretreatment. The NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Peaks at temperatures of <500°C were assigned to NH3 desorbed from weakly acidic sites, whereas peaks at >500°C were assigned to NH3 desorbed from strongly acidic sites. The densities of weakly and strongly acidic sites were also calculated from the amount of NH3 desorption and are listed in Table S3; the catalysts can be roughly classified into three groups based on their acidic properties. The first group comprises Rh/α-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2, and Rh/SiO2-MgO, which showed large desorption peaks in both low- and high-temperature ranges, indicating the presence of both weakly and strongly acidic sites. Rh/SiO2-MgO had the highest densities of strongly acidic sites and total acidic sites, 2.40 and 3.40 mmol g−1, respectively. The second group consists of Rh/SiO2-Al2O3, Rh/γ-Al2O3, and Rh/Y2O3, which showed relatively small peaks in both temperature ranges, indicating that the densities of both types of acidic sites on these catalysts were low, particularly for Rh/Y2O3, which had the lowest density of total acidic sites (0.37 mmol g−1). The third group comprises Rh/CeO2, Rh/ZrO2, Rh/SiO2-TiO2, and Rh/TiO2, each of which showed an intense peak at around 300–400°C and small peaks in the high-temperature range. These results suggest that most of the acidic sites on these four catalysts were only weakly acidic. Taken together, the results shown in Table 1 and Figs. 1 and 2 indicate that the type of support markedly influenced the Rh particle size, reducibility, and acidic properties of the Rh catalysts. Rh/γ-Al2O3 had the smallest Rh particles (3.0 nm), and Rh/α-Al2O3 had the largest (15.6 nm). During H2 reduction pretreatment at 500°C over Rh/Y2O3 and Rh/SiO2-MgO, both the Rh particles and the support surface were reduced (Fig. 1). The Rh/α-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2, and Rh/SiO2-MgO catalysts had high densities of strongly acidic sites (Fig. 2). These differences in physicochemical properties can be expected to have influenced the DRM activity of the catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic performance of supported Rh (5%) catalysts The catalytic performances of the supported Rh (5%) catalysts for DRM—as indicated by H2 yield, CO yield, and H2/CO molar ratio in the syngas product after 5 min and 8 h on stream—were investigated at 600, 500, and 400°C (Tables 2–4 , respectively). At 600°C, the H2 and CO yields over Rh/α-Al2O3 gradually decreased with time on stream, but no noticeable deactivation was observed for any of the other catalysts (data not shown). As shown in Table 2, Rh/SiO2-TiO2 showed the highest activity: after 8 h on stream, the H2 and CO yields were 37.3% and 53.1%, respectively. The product yields over the other catalysts decreased in the order Rh/SiO2 ≈ Rh/γ-Al2O3 ≈ Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 > Rh/TiO2 ≈ Rh/ZrO2 ≈ Rh/SiO2-MgO ≈ Rh/Y2O3 ≈ Rh/CeO2 > Rh/α-Al2O3. After 8 h on stream, the H2/CO ratios in the outlet gas ranged from 0.72 to 0.81 and were less affected by the support type than were the product yields. A H2/CO ratio of <1 indicates that the reverse water–gas shift reaction (reaction (4)) proceeded simultaneously with DRM. When the reaction temperature was decreased from 600 to 500°C, the catalytic activity decreased markedly. After 8 h on stream, the H2 yields, the CO yields, and the H2/CO ratios at 500°C were 5.8–11.0%, 8.3–19.2%, and 0.55–0.75, respectively (Table 3). The order of the catalyst activities at 500°C was similar to that at 600°C; that is, Rh/SiO2-TiO2 showed the highest H2 and CO yields, and Rh/α-Al2O3 showed the lowest. However, unlike in the reaction at 600°C, in the reactions at 500 and 400°C, Rh/SiO2 and Rh/SiO2-MgO were not effective, and their activities gradually decreased with time on stream. Figure 3 shows the time courses of the H2 and CO yields and the H2/CO ratios over Rh/SiO2-TiO2, Rh/α-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2-MgO, and Rh/SiO2 at 400°C. Over the most active catalyst (Rh/SiO2-TiO2), the H2 and CO yields and the H2/CO ratio were almost constant during the 8 h reaction; whereas over Rh/α-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2-MgO, and Rh/SiO2, these three parameters decreased monotonically with time on stream. The decrease in the H2 yield (Fig. 3a) was much larger than the decrease in the CO yield (Fig. 3b), indicating that the catalyst deactivation may have been induced by loss of CH4 activation sites. As shown in Fig. 2, Rh/α-Al2O3, Rh/SiO2-MgO, and Rh/SiO2 had higher densities of strongly acidic sites than the other Rh catalysts. Therefore, we propose that over these three catalysts, CH4 cracking (CH4 → CH x + (4 − x)/2 H2) proceeded at strongly acidic sites on the supports soon after the start of the reaction, resulting in excess H2 production. However, the density of strongly acidic sites gradually decreased during the reaction, owing to the adsorption of water produced by the reverse water–gas shift reaction (reaction (4)); and the decrease resulted in suppression of excess H2 production. This proposal is supported by the fact that the activity of the spent Rh(5%)/SiO2 catalyst could be recovered by calcining it at 500°C under an Ar flow to remove the adsorbed water (Fig. S2). In contrast, the other seven Rh catalysts, which had lower densities of strongly acidic sites, did not deactivate during the 8 h reaction period. The H2 and CO yields and H2/CO ratios over the supported Rh (5%) catalysts at 400°C are listed in Table 4. Rh/SiO2-TiO2 showed the highest activity, with H2 and CO yields of 1.8% and 4.2%, respectively, after 8 h on stream. The final CO yields obtained with the ten tested catalysts decreased in the order Rh/SiO2-TiO2 > Rh/γ-Al2O3 > Rh/TiO2 > Rh/ZrO2 > Rh/CeO2 > Rh/Y2O3 > Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 > Rh/SiO2-MgO > Rh/α-Al2O3 > Rh/SiO2, which was similar to the order at 500°C. The above-described results indicate that the influence of the support type on the DRM activity of the Rh catalysts varied with reaction temperature. Supports with higher densities of strongly acidic sites (e.g., α-Al2O3, SiO2, and SiO2-MgO) had lower activities than supports with lower acidic site densities. Rh/SiO2-TiO2 was the most active catalyst for DRM at 400–600°C. 3.3 Effects of support type and Rh particle size on catalytic activity The influence of Rh particle size on TOF was investigated (Fig. 4 ). TOF was calculated from the initial CO production rate at 400°C and the Rh surface area as measured by H2 pulse adsorption. Supported Rh catalysts with different Rh particle sizes were prepared by varying the Rh loading from 0.5 to 5 wt%. Regardless of the type of support, Rh particle size increased with increasing Rh loading; the ranges were estimated to be 4.8–8.8 nm for Rh/SiO2-TiO2, 1.6–3.9 nm for Rh/ZrO2, 1.5–10.0 nm for Rh/Y2O3, 3.3–15.6 nm for Rh/α-Al2O3, 5.0–8.5 nm for Rh/CeO2, 4.1–14.9 nm for Rh/TiO2, 2.6–4.1 nm for Rh/SiO2, 2.0–3.0 nm for Rh/γ-Al2O3, 2.3–3.5 nm for Rh/SiO2-MgO, and 2.5–3.1 nm for Rh/SiO2-Al2O3 (Table S4). TOF increased with decreasing Rh particle size regardless of the support type, although the slope of the increase varied with the support type (Fig. 4). This relationship suggests that DRM over supported Rh catalysts at 400°C was structure-sensitive and that coordinative unsaturated sites on the Rh metal surface or Rh sites in the vicinity of the Rh–support perimeter were the active sites for DRM. To clarify the effects of the catalyst support on TOF, the TOFs of catalysts with similar Rh particle sizes (4.0 ± 1.0 nm) but different supports were compared (Table 5 ). It was found that TOFs calculated from initial rates of CO production varied considerably with the support type, ranging from 0.03 to 0.76 s−1. This result clearly shows that the support influenced not only the Rh dispersion and reducibility but also the intrinsic activity of the Rh metal particles. In other words, the activity of the Rh catalysts was strongly influenced by the state of the Rh sites around the Rh–support perimeter. As shown in Table 5, the Rh/TiO2 catalyst showed the highest TOF value. Overall, Rh catalysts supported on reducible metal oxides such as TiO2, CeO2, and Y2O3 tended to show high TOFs, whereas those supported on irreducible metal oxides such as SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 showed low TOFs. The activation energies of the Rh catalysts (Table 5) were calculated from Arrhenius plots of the initial conversion rates of CH4, and CO2 at 600, 550, 500, 450, and 400°C (a representative plot for Rh(0.5%)/TiO2 is shown in Fig. 5 ). The activation energies of these Rh catalysts ranged from 62.0 to 78.8 kJ mol−1 for CH4 and from 51.3 to 82.3 kJ mol−1 for CO2, respectively (Table 5), and these ranges are similar to previously reported ranges for supported Rh catalysts (53–115 kJ mol−1 for CH4 and 49–102 kJ mol−1 for CO2) [6, 19, 20, 26, 54]. For all the catalysts except Rh/SiO2, the activation energy for CH4 conversion was higher than that for CO2 conversion, and this result indicates that CH4 activation was more pronounced than CO2 activation over the tested catalysts. The data in Table 5 also show that the activation energies of all the Rh catalysts except Rh(5%)/SiO2 were similar (62.0–70.5 kJ mol−1 for CH4 and 51.3–67.6 kJ mol−1 for CO2). In addition, the activation energies of Rh/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts with different Rh loadings did not depend on Rh particle size (52.4–65.8 kJ mol−1 for CH4 and 41.0–52.7 kJ mol−1 for CO2, Table S5). These results indicate that the quality of active sites around the Rh–support perimeter was independent of the support type and Rh particle size. Therefore, the variation of TOFs with support type was attributed to the number of active sites generated around the Rh–support perimeter. For example, over Rh/TiO2 and Rh/SiO2-TiO2, large numbers of active sites were generated because of the strong interaction between the Rh metal particles and the support, resulting in high TOFs. In contrast, over Rh/SiO2 and Rh/SiO2-MgO, fewer active sites were generated owing to the weak interaction between the Rh metal particles and the support, resulting in low TOFs. To determine the electronic state of the Rh metal particles, CO-TPD profiles of Rh/SiO2-TiO2 catalysts with different Rh loadings were measured (Fig. 6 ). As the Rh loading was decreased from 5 to 0.5 wt%, the Rh particle size decreased from 8.8 to 4.8 nm and the TOF (CO) increased from 0.23 to 0.71 (Fig. 4 and Table S4). The assignments of the peaks in the CO-TPD profiles of Rh catalysts have previously been reported [55–58]. Low-temperature peaks (<500°C) are assigned to associatively adsorbed CO species on Rh sites, and high-temperature peaks (>500°C) are assigned to dissociatively adsorbed CO species [55, 56]. The low-temperature peaks are further divided into three peaks: (1) a desorption peak centered at ca. 150°C attributed to the linearly adsorbed CO species [CO(l)], (2) a peak at ca. 250°C corresponding to a geminal-dicarbonyl Rh+(CO)2 species [CO(gdc)], and (3) a peak at ca. 400°C assigned to a bridge-bonded CO species [CO(b)] [57, 58]. As the Rh loading was decreased, the proportion of associatively adsorbed CO species decreased and that of dissociatively adsorbed CO species increased (Fig. 6), indicating that decreasing the Rh particle size promoted dissociative adsorption. The CO desorption temperature also decreased with decreasing Rh loading (Fig. 6), which indicates that the Rh–CO bond strength decreased with decreasing Rh particle size. It is generally accepted that CO–metal bonding is induced by electron transfer from the CO(5σ) orbital into empty bands of the metal (σ-donation) and by electron transfer from occupied bands of the metal to the CO(2π*) orbital (π-back donation). If the electron density of the Rh metal decreases, π-back donation decreases, which can be expected to weaken the Rh–CO bond. In contrast, if the electron density of the Rh metal increases, the Rh–CO bond can be expected to strengthen, owing to promotion of π-back donation. On the basis of the results described in this section, we propose that the electron density of the Rh metal particles on the Rh/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst decreased with decreasing Rh particle size owing to an electronic interaction between the Rh particles and the support. In other words, over the small Rh particles, large amounts of electron-deficient Rhδ+ species may form near the Rh–support interface, and the formation of these species can be expected to lead to an increase in the DRM activity of the catalyst. FT-IR spectra of CO adsorbed on Rh(5%)/SiO2 and Rh(5%)/SiO2-TiO2 were measured to examine the electric state of Rh metal particles (Fig. S3). From the spectrum of Rh/SiO2, two peaks were observed at 2060 and 1926 cm−1. These peaks were assigned to CO adsorbed on atop and hollow sites of Rh metal surface, respectively [59]. In contrast, the spectrum of Rh(5%)/SiO2-TiO2 showed not only peaks assigned to atop- and hollow-CO adsorption (2065 and 1917 cm−1) but also shoulder peaks at 2088 and 2020–1990 cm−1, which can be assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric carbonyl stretching frequencies of gem-dicarbonyl Rh+(CO)2 adsorbed on isolated Rh+/Rhδ+ sites. [56, 60]. This result supports the formation of Rhδ+ species over Rh/SiO2-TiO2. Acceleration of DRM by the coexistence of Rh metal and Rhδ+ species has been reported for Rh/ZrO2-Al2O3 [31], Rh/La2Ti2O7 [39], and Rh-CeO2/Al2O3 [51]. Although the role of the electron-deficient Rhδ+ species is not fully understood, it has been proposed that the coexistence of Rh metal and Rhδ+ species facilitates CH4 dissociation [31, 51] or enhances the mobility of active oxygen species (i.e., oxidation of intermediate carbon) [39], which in turn results in enhancement of catalytic activity. An increase in catalytic activity resulting from the coexistence of metallic Rh and oxidized Rh (Rh+ or Rh3+) has also been reported for partial oxidation of CH4 (CH4 + 1/2O2 → 2H2 + CO) catalyzed by Rh/CeO2-ZrO2 [61] and Rh/Ti-SiO2 [62]. As for the mechanism of DRM over supported Rh catalysts, activation of the C–H bond of CH4 is generally accepted to be the rate-determining step [42, 63, 64]. Dissociation of CH4 (CH4 → C* + 4H) over Rh metal sites forms an intermediate carbon species, which is rapidly oxidized by active oxygen species generated by CO2 dissociation (CO2 → CO + O*) over Rh metal sites and the support surface. Dissociative adsorption of CH4 over Rh metal sites can be expected to be induced by electron donation from the highest occupied molecular orbital of CH4 to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital of metallic Rh on the surface [51]. When electron transfer from Rh metal particles to the support produces electron-deficient Rhδ+ species around the Rh–support perimeter, these species may promote cleavage of the C–H bond of CH4 by accepting more electrons from the C–H bond than the catalysts composed only of Rh metal, resulting in high specific activity for DRM. Studies aimed at clarifying the role of electron-deficient Rhδ+ species are currently being carried out in our laboratory, and more-active Rh catalysts for DRM at low temperatures are under development. Conclusions In this study, the effects of the support type and the Rh particle size on the activity of supported Rh catalysts for DRM at moderate temperatures (400–600°C) were elucidated. Catalysts with different supports and different Rh particle sizes were prepared by means of an impregnation method, and the resulting catalysts were characterized by means of N2 adsorption, H2 pulse adsorption, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, CO-TPD and FT-IR. The performance of the catalysts was tested in a fixed-bed flow reactor, and their activity was found to depend strongly on their acidic properties, the support type, and the Rh particle size. Catalysts with a high density of strongly acidic sites showed low activity and gradually deactivated with time on stream, whereas catalysts with a low density of strongly acidic sites showed high, stable activity. The Rh/SiO2-TiO2 catalyst exhibited the best performance, with H2 and CO yields of 1.8% and 4.2%, respectively, at 400°C. Specific activity increased with decreasing Rh particle size, indicating that DRM over these supported Rh catalysts was structure-sensitive. Furthermore, for Rh catalysts with similar Rh particle sizes, TOF varied considerably with support type, indicating that the support influenced not only the dispersion and reducibility of the Rh particles but also the intrinsic activity of the Rh catalyst. CO-TPD and FT-IR indicated that the electronic interactions between the Rh particles and the support may have generated electron-deficient Rhδ+ species around the Rh–support perimeter, and these species may have promoted CH4 dissociation and improved DRM activity. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane at 400–600°C was studied over Rh catalysts with different supports (SiO2, γ-Al2O3, α-Al2O3, TiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, Y2O3, SiO2-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO, SiO2-TiO2), Rh particle sizes (1.5–15.6 nm), and acidic properties (acidic site density, 0.37–3.40 mmol g−1). Catalysts with a high density of strongly acidic sites (e.g., α-Al2O3, SiO2-MgO) showed low activity and gradually deactivated with time on stream; in contrast, catalysts with a low density of strongly acidic sites (e.g., TiO2, γ-Al2O3) showed high, stable activity. Rh/SiO2-TiO2 showed the best performance, with H2 and CO yields of 1.8% and 4.2% at 400°C and yields 37.3% and 53.1% at 600°C, respectively. Catalyst activity depended strongly on Rh particle size; specific activity increased with decreasing particle size, indicating that Rh-catalyzed dry reforming of methane is structure-sensitive. The support type influenced not only the dispersion and reducibility of the Rh particles but also the specific activity of the catalysts. CO temperature-programmed desorption and FT-IR suggested that electron-deficient Rhδ+ species were generated by electronic interactions between the Rh particles and the support, and the number of these species strongly influenced the overall catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of rhodium catalyst support and particle size on dry reforming of methane at moderate temperatures
